statement.tex: \text{Differentiate the following with respect to x.}\\ \qquad f(x) = \sqrt{e^{\sqrt{x}}}, x \geq 0

step.reason: \text{We have simply applied the Chain Rule to find f'(x).}\\ \text{Also, used the standard results - } \\ \dfrac{d}{dy}e^y = e^y \text{ and }\dfrac{d}{dz}\sqrt{z} = \dfrac{1}{2\sqrt{z}}.

step.context: \textbf{Bonus Question:}\text{ Are f(x) and f'(x) defined}\\ \text{for the same values of x?}
step.tex: \textbf{No. }\text{For }f(x) = \sqrt{e^{\sqrt{x}}}\text{ to be defined, }x\geq 0.\\ \text{But for }f'(x) = \dfrac{e^{\sqrt{x}}}{4\cdot\sqrt{x\cdot e^{\sqrt{x}}}}\text{ to be defined}\\ x\neq 0 \implies x\gt 0.
\textbf{Yes. } f(x)\text{ is defined for }x\geq 0. \text{And so is }f'(x).
